conclusion: Employ conservation of linear momentum and kinetic‐energy for the perfectly elastic impact because there are no external impulses along the line of centres (the incline).
Let the velocities just before impact be P: +v0 (up-slope) and Q: 0.
Let vP1 and vQ1 be the velocities immediately after the collision (positive up the slope).
For a one-dimensional, perfectly elastic collision of two point masses m (P) and 4m (Q).
Momentum along the incline: m v0 = m vP1 + 4m vQ1 ⇒ v0 = vP1 + 4 vQ1
Kinetic-energy along the incline: ½ m v0² = ½ m vP1² + ½ (4m) vQ1² ⇒ v0² = vP1² + 4 vQ1²
Solve (1) and (2). From (1) vP1 = v0 − 4 vQ1.
Expand and simplify: v0² = v0² − 8 v0 vQ1 + 16 vQ1² + 4 vQ1² ⇒ 0 = −8 v0 vQ1 + 20 vQ1²
Non-zero solution: −8 v0 + 20 vQ1 = 0 ⇒ vQ1 = (8/20) v0 = (2/5) v0.
The negative sign means P reverses its direction and moves down the incline after the impact.
Magnitude of P’s velocity just after the first collision: vP1 = 3/5 v0 (directed down the slope).
Magnitude of Q’s velocity just after the first collision: vQ1 = 2/5 v0 (directed up the slope).
